div1.p: Hench attempts to resolve the differences of memory between the yellow fever experiment survivors. The number of buildings in the yellow fever section is in question and the camp's exact location is unclear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Gustaf E. Lambert, January 20, 1947

January 20, 1947 Mr. Gust Lambert
8009 Avalon Avenue
Chicago 19, Illinois
My dear Mr. Lambert:

I wish to thank you very much indeed for your letter which I received
January 9, 1947 with your comments and corrections of the interview that we
had here June 21, 1946. I should have sent you long ago a copy of the interview
to correct but was too busy to do so. I agree with you that some of the mistakes
in the typed copy of our interview were clerical and did not represent exactly
what you said. I am very glad to have the corrections. I appreciate it very
much. The next time I send you a lot of questions I wish that you would hire
someone to typewrite your answers and let me pay the expense--that would save
you time and trouble, especially in view of your failing eyesight.

In your letter received January 9th you stated that I had not returned
to you Andrus' letter to Lewis and Sheppard. That was an oversight on my part
and I now return the letter to Lewis and one to Representative McLean. I think
you must have meant that one as I have none to Senator Sheppard. I am absolutely
sure of that as I have looked over everything I have.

Since receiving your corrections, I have spent a good deal of time
trying to solve certain differences of opinion between you and others--chiefly
of the number of little huts in the yellow fever section, who was in these huts,
et cetera. I have written out quite a memorandum for General Truby as we have
been discussing the same questions and I am enclosing a copy of part of that
memorandum. My old maps of Camp Columbia, even the 1899 and 1900 maps, distinctly
show eight little buildings just across the railroad track. Also the Yldefonso
model of Camp Columbia, made in 1900 by one of the men at the Camp hospital
and fastened securely to a wooden base and later exhibited in the Carlisle
Barracks, this model also shows eight little buildings. If you will use a
hand lens you will see that the little buildings in the model resemble very
closely the buildings in the photograph which I found in the scrapbook of
Mrs. Walter Reed. Also in reviewing some data which I got from the National
Archives I came across the records of Camp Columbia Hospital, beginning when
it was the Second Division Hospital, and the first entry indicates that there
were in 1899 already constructed “four little buildings in the yellow fever
section” and there were under construction also “four little buildings in the
small pox section.” Since this is specifically mentioned and since the maps
of 1899 and 1900, which I enclose, all contain eight buildings I must conclude
that there actually were eight. It is possible that only four were used for
wards and the other four were used for other purposes--or not used while you
were there. Were the four yellow fever buildings sufficiently separated from
the other four little buildings so that in discussing the matter you have dis-
regarded them?

Another point--according to your description and diagram the four
little buildings more or less faced each other; that is the first two buildings
-2-
across the railroad track faced west, the next two buildings faced east. You
will see that they all face west in the Reed scrapbook photograph or in the
Yldefonso model. I enclose pictures. The pictures of the Yldefonso model
which I enclose were taken after the little buildings were taken off their
permanent base and set up on the grounds of Carlisle Barracks but the relative
position and direction of the buildings was not changed as I have photographs
of the original model as was fastened down on the baseboard.

I would appreciate greatly your thoughtful review of the comments
that I enclose.

In my previous letter I did not accept your statement that Ames
became a major. I was told specifically that he was never commissioned in the
regular army. That is true. But you also are correct. I have a copy of Ames'
military record from the A. G. O. It states “Ames' contract was annulled on
his acceptance on April 26, 1901 of an appointment of Captain and Assistant
Surgeon of Volunteers---. He was appointed Major and Surgeon of Volunteers
January 6, 1902 and was ordered to Manila.” You were right, therefore, in
saying that he became a commissioned officer; however, this note to my mind
definitely indicates why Ames was transferred from Columbia Barracks to Pirotechnia,
not as punishment as you thought, but because, being commissioned, he was then
given a more responsible and more military assignment.

I have further looked up the records which indicate that General Kean
had nothing whatever to do with the transfer of yourself or Doctor Ames. When
these transfers occurred Major Kean had ceased to be Chief Surgeon. General
Lee's department was abolished about November 15, 1900 and Kean he was on duty on
General Wood's Staff May, 1901. You must believe me when I say that he had
nothing to do with the transfer of Ames or yourself.

I understood from you and from your correspondence with Doctor Brumby
that special order No. 83 had just recently been discovered. As a matter of
fact, in reviewing my file on Doctor Ames I find that Mrs. Ames has long had
that special order No. 83. I have so much material that I can't keep it all
in my head at one time but around 1940 Mrs. Ames loaned me some material and
I find at that time she had special order No. 83.

I enclose various maps and photographs to show the indications that
there were at first, between 1899 and 1902, eight little huts across the rail-
road track. In the 1907 map (enclosed) only five are marked as being present.
Please note that on the 1899 map the two western most little buildings are
labeled “kitchen.” They may have been used for that purpose by the Second
Division Hospital. Incidentally, will you please tell me from whence you got
your food--the food for yourself and the food for your patients when they were
convalescing? Was it cooked in the post hospital and brought to you or did
you prepare it in one of the little buildings? Being under quarantine I don't
imagine you went to a mess. I realize that during the first few days of your
patients' illness they received practically no food, but later, while they were
getting better--when their fever had disappeared but before they were ready
for convalescent discharge, didn't they receive some food? If so, where was
it prepared?

Very sincerely,
P. S. Hench, M. D.
